awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Religion-Related Bias Victimization: Addressing a Blind-Spot
awd_abstract_narration:
Evidence suggests that crimes targeting individuals based on their religion are on the rise. This harms not only the well-being of victims, but also the well-being of their communities and the nation. Existing data assessing criminal victimization and bias-motivated crimes do not adequately measure the religion of victims or the role of religion in bias-motivated crimes. This project will provide new data by conducting a nationally representative survey of adults to assess their experiences with victimization and whether they perceived that religious bias was a motivator for their being victimized.  This project will provide much-needed information to assist law enforcement, communities, and policy-makers in better preventing religion-related crimes and serving the victims of such crimes. 


The project will field a survey using a nationally representative sample of 1,000 US adults along with oversamples of several minority religious groups totaling 1,200 additional respondents. The survey instrument will utilize both original questions along with questions drawn from existing surveys. The instrument will measure individuals' experiences with criminal victimization with a specific interest in whether religion was perceived to be a motivator for the offender(s) and the impact of the experience on the victim. The project will augment the survey data by attaching indicators from the U. S. Census that reflect community characteristics such as racial composition and median household income.  Use of the 2010 Religious Congregations and Membership Study will permit attaching data on the religious composition of respondent neighborhoods.  The data generated from this survey will be analyzed using regression models predicting outcomes such as the risk of victimization, fears of victimization, and the impact and responses to victimization. Findings will inform theories in several sociological subfields including the sociology of religion, criminology and collective action.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the “Religion-Related Bias Victimization: Addressing a Blind Spot” project was to measure individuals’ experiences with religious discrimination and victimization. To address the lack of existing datasets that assess these issues, we sought to field a nationally representative survey of US adults (with oversamples of Muslims, Buddhists, atheists and other minority religious groups) and to conduct follow-up interviews with a subset of survey respondents to examine the relationship between religion and the risk of victimization, fear of victimization, and the impact and responses to victimization.

We have achieved (and exceeded) our goals for new data collection through this study. In total, we surveyed 4,774 respondents (including 1,572 respondents from targeted oversample populations) and completed 48 follow-up interviewers with survey takers. Analyses of these data are ongoing. Major statistical findings to date include: vastly greater proportions of Muslim and Jewish individuals report experience with religious discrimination and victimization when compared to Christians. These patterns are unchanged after accounting for differences in race and ethnicity, language usage, and national origin, suggesting these religious patterns are not simply the result of other socio-demographic differences.

Looking at particular types of discrimination and victimization, we find, for example, that Muslim individuals, report much more harassment by the police, with the greatest salience among Muslims identifying as Black or Middle Eastern/Arab/North African. From analyses conducted for another paper, we find that political identification is a predictor of identity concealment among atheists and that atheists who identify as Republican are more likely to say that they conceal their identity as an atheist. Other findings relate to the mental and physical well-being consequences of having experiences with religious discrimination and victimization, as well as attitudes about anti-Muslim policies in the U.S. For another paper, our analyses show that the collective memory of past and contemporary religious victimization may continue to affect Jewish and Muslim adults via a mechanism of fear, which has implications for scholarly and policy efforts to decrease religious victimization and its impacts. These findings have been or will be described in full in peer-reviewed journal articles.

With respect to qualitative analyses, we have examined different contexts where respondents encounter or experience discrimination, including educational contexts, healthcare facilities, travel, and in their neighborhoods or other public spaces. We have also examined the reasons people choose to report or not report discrimination; the reasons why people perceive discrimination as religious and when this overlaps with other forms of discrimination (race, gender, sexuality, disability, politics); and how religion/faith has been a resource for coping with or responding to discrimination.

Underscoring what our quantitative analyses tell us, we find that many of our Muslim respondents described instances of extreme discrimination and victimization -- often by strangers in public. Several described instances of feeling targeted specifically due to their physical appearance, including attire (especially head coverings) and their race. Similarly, Orthodox Jewish respondents who wear religious attire also shared experiences of verbal harassment in public. By comparison, no Christian respondents described instances of public harassment or assault by strangers due to their religion. However, they did discuss feeling socially excluded or stereotyped in settings like the workplace. Atheist and non-religious respondents also described social othering or exclusion in workplace settings in contexts where they were a known religious minority. Overall, these emerging themes help illuminate the different contexts in which people from different faith traditions may encounter discrimination and experience victimization, but also illustrate the differential ways that groups may be impacted by discrimination and victimization.  

As our analyses have progressed, the project team has focused on dissemination efforts, which will continue in the months and years ahead. To date, the project team has published one academic article, has five more academic articles in development or at the revise and resubmit stage, has completed two academic conference presentations, (with one more upcoming), has published a press release, and data from the project have been incorporated by junior scholars of the research team into one master’s thesis and two coursework papers. This is in addition to a book manuscript that is being developed by the project PIs.

Finally, this project has served as an important training ground for junior scholars who learned research methods and social science approaches to studying religion-related discrimination and victimization in the United States through the study and those who want to connect social science research to policy, including 18 undergraduate, graduate, post-doctoral and staff researchers.
